case_vignette:
A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain, tingling, and numbness in his right hand that started 3 months ago. It is worse at night and frequently wakes him up. The symptoms can be relieved by shaking his hands but soon recur. He reports weakness of his right hand, especially when grasping objects. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are metformin and sitagliptin. Four months ago he went on a camping trip. He has been working as a hardscaper for 8 years. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows reproduction of his symptoms when his right hand is held above his head for 2 minutes. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,600/mm3
Hemoglobin A1C 6.3%
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 13 mm/h
question: Which  is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing pain, tingling, and numbness in my right hand, especially at night, and it often wakes me up.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
These symptoms started 3 months ago.
Have you noticed if certain activities or positions make your symptoms worse?
Yes, it gets worse at night, and when I keep my right hand above my head for a couple of minutes, the symptoms come back.
Do you have any weakness in your hand or difficulty performing tasks?
Yes, I've been feeling weakness in my right hand, especially when I try to grasp objects.
Do you have any other medical conditions or are you on any medications?
I have type 2 diabetes and I'm taking metformin and sitagliptin for it.
Have you had any previous injuries or surgeries to your neck, shoulder, or hand?
No injuries or surgeries mentioned.
Is there a family history of neurological conditions or similar symptoms?
No family history mentioned.
Do you experience any changes in coordination, or have you noticed any muscle wasting in your hand?
No changes in coordination or muscle wasting mentioned.
Have you tried any treatments or interventions for your symptoms so far?
Shaking my hands seems to relieve the symptoms temporarily.
Does your job or daily routine involve repetitive hand or wrist movements?
Yes, I've been working as a hardscaper for 8 years which involves repetitive hand movements.
Final Diagnosis: Carpal tunnel syndrome.

The patient notes that shaking the hands provides temporary relief from the symptoms. The patient has been working as a hardscaper for the past 8 years, which involves repetitive hand movements.
